entry.title: A New Site for the New Year
entry.content:
For about the last year, my personal task list has included “start a blog“ but somehow it never bubbled to the top, despite constant encouragement (and sometimes ridicule) from my blog-crazed friends. I think most of them probably grew tired of asking me “when are you going to start a blog?“ and assumed it would never happen.

Well, never say never. I just finished writing my latest column for MSDN Magazine, where I addressed the topic of blogging technologies (to be published next month). This exercise, along with the hope of a new year, was enough to finally push me over the edge and get it done. I've decided to call my blog “The XML Files.”

I also took this opporutinity to do some general Web site housekeeping by bringing over the most popular content from my old site (see “My Stuff“ in the left-hand menu), which will soon be retired.

Update: My old site will still be available for a few months while I'm working through the transition. If a link doesn't work on this site, you can find the bits on the old site for now.

entry.title: Essential WinInet
entry.content:
[Book Site][Amazon]

by Aaron Skonnard (Addison Wesley)

The era of stand-alone, self-contained applications is rapidly ending. Distributed, networked applications have become critical to meeting business needs in a fast-paced, dynamic world. Until now, building networked Windows applications wasn't easy. But now Microsoft has released a powerful new Windows Internet API (WinInet) that dramatically simplifies the process of creating Internet-enabled Windows applications.

WinInet makes it possible to create Windows applications that can download Web pages, access server applications, upload and download files, and traverse Gopher document systems--allowing developers to build such sophisticated Windows Internet applications as full-fledged Web browsers, home banking applications, and stock portfolio programs.

entry.title: re: Essential WinInet
Essential XML
entry.content:
[Book Site][Amazon]

by Don Box, Aaron Skonnard, and John Lam (Addison Wesley)

The Extensible Markup Language (XML) has been anointed as the universal duct tape for all software integration problems despite XML's relatively humble origins in the world of document management systems. Essential XML presents a software engineering-focused view of XML and investigates how XML can be used as a component integration technology much like COM or CORBA. Written for software developers, this book demonstrates how XML can be used as the glue between independently developed software components (or in the marketecture terminology du jour, how XML can act as the backplane for B2B e-commerce applications).

Readers acquire a better understanding of XML's inner workings and come to see how its platform, language, and vendor independence--along with its accessibility--make it an extraordinarily effective solution for software interoperation.

entry.title: Essential XML Quick Reference
entry.content:
[Book Site][Amazon]

by Aaron Skonnard and Martin Gudgin (Addison Wesley)

New! The entire book is now available online in a searchable electronic format (PDF). We hope you find it useful. Enjoy!

This book is for anyone working with today's mainstream XML technologies. It was specifically designed to serve as a handy but thorough quick reference that answers the most common XML-related technical questions. It goes beyond the traditional pocket reference design by providing complete coverage of each topic along with plenty of meaningful examples.

Each chapter provides a brief introduction, which is followed by the detailed reference information. This approach assumes the reader has a basic understanding of the given topic. The detailed outline (at the beginning), index (in the back), bleeding tabs (along the side), and the page headers/footers were designed to help readers quickly find answers to their questions.

Notable Quotes

"A handy, comprehensive reference guide to all the latest XML and Web services technologies. Skonnard and Gudgin give you all the details in one place."
  --Noah Mendelsohn, Distinguished Engineer, IBM and Lotus Development Corporation, and coeditor of W3C XML Schema Recommendation

"If you are building XML-aware applications, attach this book to your utility belt. You'll need it."
  --Mark Fussell, Program Manager for the XML Framework in .NET, Microsoft

"This book is a unique collection of reference material on the most relevant XML-related standards, which takes the important W3C recommendations and puts them all in context. Something that definitely needs to be on every XML developer's desk!"
  --Alexander Falk, President and CEO of Altova, Inc., The XML Spy Company

"I think it is a wonderfully clear and concise summary of a great deal of key XML material. I expect it to find a well-thumbed home on my bookshelf."
  --Mary Holstege, PhD, XML Architect, mathling.com, and W3C XML Schema Working Group Member

"Finally, a complete and thorough reference book covering all of the most important XML technologies, including the latest addition (XML Schema), in one concise and consistent presentation. I will definitely have this book close at hand."
  --Chris Lovett, Product Unit Manager, B2B Web Services, Microsoft

"Essential XML Quick Reference is one of the few printed references I would actually buy."
  --Don Box, Series Editor, The DevelopMentor Series

entry.title: xpath.js
entry.content:
xpath.js is a command-line utility for selecting subsets of an XML document. Requires MSXML 4.0.

The help information is displayed if you run the utility from the command-line without supplying any arguments:

C:>xpath
MSXML XPath Utility

usage: xpath fname xpath:xpathExpr [options]
  -o  outputFile
  -ns prefix nsURI

The following example searches for all all Price elements from the http://example.org/invoice namespace:

C:\>xpath invoice.xml xpath://x:Price -ns x http://example.org/invoice

The result of the transformation will be displayed in the console if you don't specify an output file name.

Download here.

entry.title: xslt.js
entry.content:
xslt.js is a command-line utility for transforming an input document against a specified XSLT transformation. Requires MSXML 4.0.

The help information is displayed if you run the utility from the command-line without supplying any arguments:

C:>xslt
MSXML XSLT Utility

usage: xslt inputFile xsltFile [options]
  -o outputFile
  -p paramName paramValue

The following example transforms input.xml using transform.xsl and saves the output to out.htm:

C:\>xslt input.xml transform.xsl -o out.htm

The result of the transformation will be displayed in the console if you don't specify an output file name.

Download here.

entry.title: re: xslt.js
entry.content:
This has been a great little utility. It gets a lot of use around here. Recently, though, I ran into an issue. The source XML I was converting was UTF-8 and included an ndash (–). After being run through an XSL transform via xslt.js (where the XSL's output was defined as UTF-8), the ndash could not be interpreted, rendering the resulting XML invalid.

The reason this happened is because xslt.js doesn't specify the third parameter to the FileSystemObject's CreateTextFile method, and so it winds up writing the output to an ASCII file.

I've modified my version of xslt.js to target Unicode files by default (passing true to the third parameter), and it accepts a command-line argument to revert to ASCII if needed.

Thanks again for this helpful utility!

entry.title: validate.js
entry.content:
validate.js is a command-line utility for validating an input document against a specified DTD or XML Schema definition. If you don't supply a DTD/schema, it simply reports whether the document is well-formed. Requires MSXML 4.0.

The help information is displayed if you run the utility from the command-line without supplying any arguments as illustrated here:

C:\>validate

usage: validate instance_file  ...

For example, the following command validates invoice.xml against invoice.xsd:

C:\>validate invoice.xml invoice.xsd

success: document conforms to DTD/Schema

If the document isn't valid, detailed error information is provided.

Download here.

entry.title: post.js
entry.content:
post.js is a command-line utility for issuing an HTTP POST request where the body contains the contents of the specifed file or the supplied string; this utility allows you to specify arbitrary HTTP headers to send along with the request. Requires MSXML 4.0.

The help information is displayed if you run the utility from the command-line without supplying any arguments:

C:\>post
HTTP POST Utility

usage: post uri [options]
  -f inputFile
  -s inputString
  -o outputFile
  -h headerName headerValue

The following example posts a SOAP request to a Web service endpoint along with a few HTTP headers:

C:\>post http://localhost/math/math.asmx -h Content-Type “text/xml“ -h SOAPAction “http://localhost/math/Add“ -f request.xml

The HTTP response is displayed in the console when don't specify an output file name.

Download here.

entry.title: Namespace Highlighter
entry.content:
Namespace Highlighter is a simple HTML tool that loads the specified XML document and highlights each XML namespace in a different color. Requires MSXML 4.0.

Download here.

entry.title: XPath Expression Compressor
entry.content:
XPath Expression Compressor provides a simple HTML interface for compressing an XPath expression with all possible abbreviations. Requires MSXML 4.0.

Download here.

entry.title: Interactive XPath Expression Builder 4.0
entry.content:
Interactive XPath Expression Builder 4.0 provides a simple HTML interface for evaluating the results of an XPath expression against a loaded XML document - the results are highlighted interactively as you type the expression. Requires MSXML 4.0.

Click here for the full-size screenshot. In addition to the basic node-set evaluation functionality, this tool supports the following features:

  • Value expressions (e.g., 'sum(//Price)') [screenshot]
  • Namespace bindings (allows you to use prefixes in your XPath expressions) [screenshot]
  • Selecting the current context node (highlighted in blue, for evaluating relative expressions) [screenshot]
  • Support for Microsoft XSD extension functions - you load a schema to associate with the document first, then use the Microsoft extension functions [screenshot]
  • User control over font-sizes and how results are highlighted

This tool is almost 4 years old and has proven helpful to many developers trying to learn the intricacies of XPath. It has been contributed to by several others including Martin Gudgin and Scott Bloom.

Download here.

entry.title: .Text vs. dasBlog
entry.content:
Deciding on a blogging engine was harder than I thought it would be. I knew I wanted a .NET implementation so that narrowed it down to two: .Text and dasBlog, the best in the .NET camp that I've seen.

Unique .Text features:

  • Database backend (SQL Server or MSDE)
  • Multiple blogs from single install (see MSDN Blogs)
  • Extensible content pages (“Articles“)
  • Extensible categories for “Articles“ & “Links“

Unique dasBlog features:

  • XML backend
  • Blogroll manager
  • “Mail to Weblog“
  • SMTP notifications
  • User can select skin
  • Installation program (.msi)
  • Many configuration options 

Putting these differences aside, they share a lot in common:

  • skins/themes
  • RSS 2.0 and Atom feeds
  • traceback and referrals
  • categories
  • comments
  • Web service access

Although I was very tempted by some of dasBlog's features, .Text won me over in the end. I wanted to unify the content from my old site with my blog, and I needed .Text's “Article“ pages to do it. There also seems to be a bit more community around the .Text implementation (e.g., you'll find more skins and probably benefit from more updates down the road). What I really we wish had was an implementation that combined the best from both: dasText?

entry.title: .NET Nightly 93
re: .Text vs. dasBlog
entry.content: .Text also has mail notifications, but only for posted comments.

entry.title: What I've been up to lately
entry.content:
For the past six months, I've been engaged at Northface University (NU), which is located right here in Salt Lake City, Utah. NU is a new university focused exlusively on computer science and leading-edge software technologies. The exciting thing about NU is that they're attempting to create a _completely_ project-driven curriculum, something that no other university has been able to fully achieve. Students that complete the program will receive an accredited BSCS degree, but more importantly, they'll walk away with an extensive digital portfolio of project work that they've completed while in school. Students will work with both .NET and Java. Check out the Web site for more details.

Many have asked if I'm still with DevelopMentor. The answer is YES, but I can only teach every few months with my new commitments. I've also decided to cut back on conferences this year, so I can live a more normal life at home.

I've also been heavily involved in the Utah .NET User Group (UNUG) as an organizer and a speaker. Several months ago we moved UNUG to Northface University, who became the new host (and main sponsor). Check out the new site that we put together based on the ASP.NET community starter kit.

entry.title: Becoming my own ISP
entry.content:
With all these changes, I also decided to become my own ISP and host things from home. Mostly because I'm sick of not having full control.

I have a Sprint Broadband connection, which gives me scream'in downloads but throttled uploads. I'll be watching to see if this becomes a problem (let me know if you notice). I configured my router to route incoming traffic to my machine, so the only thing left was DNS. Last night I changed the DNS entries with my registrar, but they still haven't fully propagated yet. I'm running Windows Server 2003 on a so-so box that I had laying around the house. I decided to use IMail Express (free) for email instead of Exchange because I only need POP and didn't want the administration headache. If anyone has any feedback or suggestions on this approach, I'd love to hear it.

entry.title: re: Becoming my own ISP
entry.content: Almost exactly the same setup I have here, right down to IMail express (the POP with 2003 server isn't bad...but IMail does give webmail as well which can be handy). So long as you turn on IIS 6.0 compression, the bandwidth is not a problem(for me at least, no doubt your site will have a lot more traffic!). Only issue I have currently is my ADSL - which goes down a lot more than I had realised previously. I use a free service here: http://uptime.openacs.org/uptime/ which sends a mail (to hotmail is handy) when your site goes down...

entry.title: An MSDN XML Developer Center?
entry.content:
It looks like Dare is pushing for an XML Developer Center on MSDN. I imagine this will not be easy. XML has always been thought of as an enabling technology, not a solution unto itself, very much like databases. Most XML-saavy developers don't think of themselves as “XML developers”, but rather as “Web developers” or “C# developers”, etc. This probably has something to do with why MSDN doesn't currently offer developer centers for SQL Server or XML.

My good friend, Tim Ewald, was one of the main driving forces behind creating the new Web Services Developer Center, which I just love. I spend time on it daily because it makes the information I need so easy to find. As Matt Powell explains, the WSDC actually pulls most of its content from the main MSDN library - there is very little duplication. You can think of it as a SQL view over the main library customized for Web service developers.

The WSDC currently provides links to the various XML bits (this is really the main entry point for XML guys besides the main library), but it doesn't cover everything. In fact, the core XML topics have been somewhat overshadowed by the various WS advances recently. Hence, a specialized view for those serious about Microsoft XML technologies seems like a win. It will be interesting to see if Dare can make it happen. Good luck!

entry.title: re: An MSDN XML Developer Center?
entry.content:
>This probably has something to do with why MSDN doesn't currently offer developer centers for SQL Server or XML.


Nope, that's not it.

Over to the Yukon site to read about XQuery and the XML data type, then over to the .NET Framework for XPathNavigator info and then over to the Longhorn site for crunchy goodness about XAML. And since there's now a XML MVP award why not?

entry.title: Data Access and Storage

entry.title: WebMethod [Validation] and [Assert] Attributes
entry.content:
This sample illustrates how to write a SoapExtension for enabling XML Schema validation on incoming SOAP messages. You can turn on validation by using the [Validation] attribute as illustrated here:

...
[Validation]
[WebMethod]
public double Add(double x, double y) {
     return x+y;
}

The validation occurs against the XML Schema generated by the .asmx infrastructure by default, although you can point the extension to your custom schema if you desire.

In addition to XML Schema validation, this extension provides support for validating arbitrary XPath assertions as illustrated here:

...
[Assert(“//l > //w“)]
[Validation]
[WebMethod]
public double CalcDistance(double l, double w) {
     return l*w;
}

This indicates that the length must be greater than width, an assertion you cannot express with XML Schema (note: you may have to use namespace prefixes depending on your WebMethod configuration).

For details of how this sample works and the functionality it provides, check out my following articles:

  • Extend the ASP.NET WebMethod Framework by Adding XML Schema Validation 
  • Extend the ASP.NET WebMethod Framework with Business Rules Validation 

Download here.

entry.title: MessagePredicate Policy Assertion Handler
entry.content:
The WSE 2.0 Technology Preview introduced support for WS-Policy and writing custom policy assertion handlers.

WS-PolicyAssertions is another policy-related specification that defines some standard policy assertions most Web services would want to use. One of these assertions is called MessagePredicate. MessagePredicate allows you to assert arbitrary expressions written in one of two dialects: XPath and SOAP message parts. Hence, with MessagePredicate, you could implement a business rules validation scheme (like the one I provided here) without writing a single line of code. Overall, I find this to be a much better way of taking care of validation needs.

Unfortunately, the WSE2 TP doesn't currently support MessagePredicate. This sample illustrates how to write a custom policy assertion handler that provides MessagePredicate support. For more details, check out my upcoming MSDN Magazine article titled "WS-Policy and WSE 2.0 Assertion Handlers".

Download here.

entry.title: MessagePredicate for Validation
entry.content:
I've spent a lot of time thinking about Web services validation. Dare, and others, have recently posted about it as well. The question is where does validation go in an SOA approach?

A new technique for approaching this problem is WS-Policy.

The WSE 2.0 Technology Preview introduced support for WS-Policy and writing custom policy assertion handlers.

WS-PolicyAssertions is another policy-related specification that defines some standard policy assertions most Web services would want to use. One of these assertions is called MessagePredicate. MessagePredicate allows you to assert arbitrary expressions written in one of two dialects: XPath and SOAP message parts. Hence, with MessagePredicate, you could implement a business rules validation scheme (like the one I provided here) without writing a single line of code. You'd simply write a policy file like the one shown here that asserts length is 5 and greater than width:

<wsp:Policy wsu:Id="policy-600686d0-b855-4f6b-9dac-9218547d462c"
  xmlns:wsp="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2002/12/policy"
  xmlns:m="http://example.org/math"
  xmlns:wsp="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2002/12/policy"
  xmlns:m="http://example.org/math"
 >
  <wsp:MessagePredicate wsp:Usage="wsp:Required">    
     //m:length > //m:width
  </wsp:MessagePredicate>
  <wsp:MessagePredicate wsp:Usage="wsp:Required">    
     //m:length = 5
  </wsp:MessagePredicate>
</wsp:Policy>  


Decoupling validation from the code is attractive because it helps long-term maintainability.

This sample illustrates how to write a custom policy assertion handler that provides MessagePredicate support. For more details, check out my upcoming MSDN Magazine article titled "WS-Policy and WSE 2.0 Assertion Handlers".

entry.title: re: MessagePredicate for Validation

http://donxml.com/allthingstechie/archive/2004/02/04/390.aspx

entry.title: Is UDDI Dead?
entry.content:
The fact that Karsten hasn't posted since last August suggests that it is. Seriously, I used to find hope in UDDI for dealing with one simple use case: helping clients deal with nomad endpoints. But the lack of adoption and decrease in hype really has me wondering if it will ever go anywhere. In a recent conversation with a friend, we jokingly concluded that UDDI has become a successful Yellow Pages; the only problem is most of the listings don't have telephones.

It also seems like WS-Addressing could help displace the need for a directory service, at least for my use case, if redirects are all handled on the backend. I'd love to hear other opinions.

entry.title: re: Is UDDI Dead?
entry.content: I think public UDDI has been a dissapointment. It seems that there would still be potential in the enterprise for UDDI. The driving requirement will only come when enterprises have more WS endpoints than they can track easily.

entry.title: re: Is UDDI Dead?
entry.content:
I've been tracking UDDI since 1.0 and I've been waiting to recommend it to a client until I see that they have some "phones hooked up".

I've continued my comment on my weblog:

http://www.cerkit.com/cerkitBlog/PermaLink.aspx?guid=aaaf8e71-2637-4ad1-893f-addca324f266

entry.title: re: Is UDDI Dead?
entry.content:
I spoke with KarstenJ about UDDI at the PDC03 he is off on a Longhorn project far removed from the world of UDDI. If you look at the US federal XML registry project ( http://xml.gov ) it seems to be going ebXML registry with linkages to UDDI. If you do look at the highlevel publicaly accessable UDDI implementations like the excellent Danish site at http://isb.oio.dk you'll notice that they really have not added much value to the base MS UDDI implementation and people tend to use it as a company placeholder.

My own hope had been to see some UDDI v3 implementations with demonstrated replication between two servers. Dunno is this possible? I mean without that UDDI is limited.

I asked AndyH of MS (ADSI guru) where MS is going and all he woudl say is that their UDDI is part of their overall Longhorn directories strategy but no further details.

I agree though without someone like KarstenJ actively promoting UDDI or even blogging/writting about UDDI then I see no one with the passion to move it forward...

entry.title: Northface University Grand Opening
entry.content: Last Friday we celebrated the Grand Opening of Northface University. Governor Olene Walker was present along with several industry influentials including John Soyring (VP IBM Software Group), Grady Booch (IBM “Free Radical”), Janie Schwark (Microsoft), and Mark Israelsen (Oracle). I've never been part of a Grand Opening before, but it was quite impressive.

entry.title: An Afternoon with Booch
entry.content:
Grady Booch sits on Northface University's Advisory Board. During our Grand Opening, he spoke to our students about careers of software development. He presented a few interesting facts about the size of the software industry today: he said there are over 12 million software developers worldwide, approximately one-third of them actually write code, and approximately 800 billion lines of code have been written to date.

He eloquently spoke about how “software has changed the world“. And he emphasized that our profession “is a noble one.” It was quite moving actually. After the ceremonies, the faculty had a chance to shmooze with Grady for a bit. This was my first encounter with Booch on a personal level - very interesting guy.

entry.title: Understanding XML Namespaces
entry.content:
Steve recently posted about the battle to understand XML namespaces and Dare responded and gave a nice explanation of some of the intricacies.

Namespaces have always been one of the hardest XML concepts to explain to developers. I did my best to explain them thoroughly in Understanding XML Namespaces as well as an older article that discussed some related API issues. Later, Dare wrote a nice piece on how XML namespaces affect XPath and XSLT.  

I haven't addressed the issue again because it seems like we've covered it to death already. Do developers still want more? A better explanation perhaps?

entry.title: Indexing XML with a Custom XmlDocument
entry.content: Mark Fussell, Lead PM on System.Xml, discusses the problems with indexing XML documents today. He also provides an interesting example of how you can create a custom indexing solution by writing a custom XmlDocument class that indexes nodes as they're loaded. The compelling thing about his solution is that it does not require a DTD or XML Schema. It relies on an undefined “id” attribue, whose value and node reference are stored in a HashTable for quick lookups via GetElementByIdAttribute.

entry.content:
Excellent article. btw, do you know if it's possible to do something similar with the tokentype element? let me explain this better. currently we're doing some tests with WSE 2.0 preview. we need to pass a custom usernametoken to the web service (it only has 2 aditional fields on it). Everything works ok. however, I'm interested in requiring the use of the token in messages sent to the web service. currently, I'm doing it through code, but I'd like to put something like that in a policy file.
after looking at the code (using anakrino), I´ve noticed that there are some methods on the UsernameTokenManager class that might be important to this. for instance, LoadSecurityTokenAssertion seems to be responsible for giving back the ISecurityTokenAssertion element which would do the verification of the token type. I've tried to build my own class, but didn´t had any success with this approach (in fact, I've tried doing some debugging and sometimes the method LoadSecurityTokenAssertion doesn't even get called - don't kow why though..). so the question is: any ideas on how to do that? am I on the right track?. thanks.

entry.title: re: Using MessagePredicate for WebMethod Validation
entry.content:
Great article. It was very interesting to follow your web services validation series.
Although I have seen one drawback in Ws-Policy assertion code comparing to Xpath Attribute assertions code :
In Soap Extension you have written in "business rules validation" article you are using XmlValidationReader - so it's doing validation against schema while loading document and then evaluating the xapth - but the whole process is in one pass.

while in the flow using WS-Policy we have to have 2 passes over the XML one for validating against the schema one for Xpath assertions ?

Is there a way to do schema validation using WS-Policy in one pass as well ?

Thank you

entry.title: re: Using MessagePredicate for WebMethod Validation
entry.content: The attribute-driven validation approach (e.g., [Validation], [Assert]) also requires multiple passes through the document: one to validate the stream and load it into the DOM, and others to evaluate the XPath expressions (if you consider that a pass). So I don't think the policy approach is less efficient.

entry.title: re: Using MessagePredicate for WebMethod Validation
entry.content: Luis, one way to accomplish what you're after is to simply use the MessagePredicate to require your custom security header (as outlined in the article). Another way is to write a custom security token manager and add a policy statement to require your token.

entry.title: re: Using MessagePredicate for WebMethod Validation
entry.content:
Hello Aaron. Yes, I've followed the "Message Predicate path". thanks for your answer.

regards,
Luis

entry.title: XML Developer Center on MSDN

entry.title: System.Xml Perf and Sun's Ploy
entry.content:
Mark provides some insight into Webdata's thoughts on System.Xml performance, spurred by a recent performance study published by Sun. I completely agree with Mark's assessment that “...usability is as important as performance and the Java APIs on the whole have significantly lagged behind System.Xml in this respect.”

The fact that most Java SAX parsers outperform .NET's XmlReader is meaningless in my opinion. Every customer I've worked with would take XmlReader's usability over the best SAX solution any day of the week, even if it means a decrease in perf. In general, XmlReader's perf is good enough for most customers needs and when you begin comparing the complexity of the soluttion code for most typical tasks, XmlReader clearly dominates.

Overall, the report seems like a transparent ploy to distract developers from noticing Sun's lack of XML innovation.

entry.title: System.XML performance vs. user unfriendly SAX?
Behind XPathDocument
entry.content: Matt Warren describes the reasoning behind XPathDocument and the specific performance improvements it provides.

entry.title: InfoPath 2003 SP-1 Preview
entry.content:
In prepration for an upcoming article, I've spent quite a bit of time with the InfoPath 2003 SP-1 Preview. All I can say is...WOW. You can tell by looking at this release that the InfoPath team is clearly listening to its customers. In fact, the InfoPath team even has their own weblog now, where they post about new features and allow for reader comments.

This post announces the preview along with download locations. They've fixed the most glaring blemishes found in the initial release and have added several significant new features.

The biggest enhancement is the new support for .NET code integration. After you install the InfoPath 2003 VS.NET toolkit, you can create new InfoPath template projects that allow you to write event handlers in C# or VB.NET.Then you can select form controls and select 'Edit Code' and it will take you into your 'code behind' file in VS.NET. For example, here's an event handler for a button click event:

...
[InfoPathEventHandler(MatchPath="Button1",
  EventType=InfoPathEventType.OnClick)]
public void Button1_OnClick(DocActionEvent e)
{
   // Write your code here
   ...
}
...

Then it's simply an exercise in XML DOM programming to work with the data in the form. You should definitely give it a whirl if you've been using InfoPath.

entry.title: Creative Learning
entry.content:
I'm continually amazed by some of the students we have at Northface University. We recently assigned them a small project designed to exercise their newly acquired C# and OO skills. The project required them to design and implement a graphics library for drawing various shapes (lines, rectangles, ellipses, etc.) on a Winforms canvas, but without using any of the built-in drawing APIs.

Most of the students accomplished this in a 3-4 day period, but some went well beyond the basic requirements and were incredibly creative. One student team (Jeremy Wilde and Jeremy Melton) implemented a marble maze game (see below) and tapped into the hard drive accelerometer that came with their IBM R50's. So to play the game you physically tilt the laptop to move the marble through the maze. They're still working on making the marble obey the line boundaries, but it's still amazing to see.

Another student (Nick Maly) caught on to the accelerometer trick and built an etch-a-sketch program that can be erased with the right amount of laptop-shaking.

I'm guess the main reason I'm floored by this is that these students just started at Northface a few months ago. Although some are having a harder time than others, the projects allow students to go at their own pace (to a degree) and to explore personal interests. It's fun to see things we never expected.

entry.title: re: Creative Learning
entry.content:
These guys seem to be pretty cool! I have to admit, that I'm myself a big fan of the joys of programming the R50s accelerometer ;)

-Ingo

entry.title: re: Creative Learning
entry.content: That sounds cool! I think that learning how to write good code & design good software systems is a creative process. Just like I think that going to school to be an 'artist' is the wrong approach, I also believe that going to school to get a standard CS degree is also the wrong approach. Unless the training represents the type of work that the student will do once they graduate. I think the most valuable thing that I learned in College was critical thinking...

entry.title: RSS Version History
entry.content:
Apparently, Dave Winer had some issues with my history of RSS (see the answer to the “Which RSS version is the most current?“ question). This prompted him to write his own RSS timeline for the records.

I'm sure Dave's account is more thorough than mine, but I was only focusing on the specs with “RSS“ in the name. The RSS version story is confusing enough already. 

It's interesting that Dave's timeline starts with the scriptingNews format in 12/97. If Dave was going for thoroughness, I'm not sure why he left out Microsoft's CDF (a very RSS-like news format with channel and item elements) that shipped back in 3/97, 9 months before the first scriptingNews format.

Don's RSS version history highlights this ommission. At least one other person has noticed CDF's place in history and did a good job poking some fun.

This is also quite interesting.

entry.title: Google's Secret Sauce
entry.content:
This is a facinating read on the source of Google's power and why they're dominating in Web-scale programming. It also helps explain how Google will face the challenge of storing 1 GB of email for millions of GMail users.

Here are some highllights:

...the story is about seemingly incremental features that are actually massively expensive for others to match, and the platform that Google is building which makes it cheaper and easier for them to develop and run web-scale applications than anyone else.

...Google has 100,000 servers. [nytimes] If a server/disk dies, they leave it dead in the rack, to be reclaimed/replaced later. Hardware failures need to be instantly routed around by software.

...Google has built their own distributed, fault-tolerant, petabyte filesystem, the Google Filesystem.

...Google now has an institutional competence building and maintaining servers that cost a lot less than the servers everyone else is using. And they do it with fewer people.

entry.title: Enabling support for .vsdisco in 1.1
entry.content:
Due to security concerns, the .vsdisco handler mapping was commented out in machine.config in .NET 1.0. You simply had to uncomment it in order to enable the .vsdisco functionality. In .NET 1.1, however, they completely removed the comment, even though the DiscoveryRequestHandler class still ships in the framework. So to enable it, you need to manually add the handler mapping back as shown here:

...
<httpHandlers>
  <add path="*.vsdisco" verb="*"
    type="System.Web.Services.Discovery.DiscoveryRequestHandler,
     System.Web.Services,
     Version=1.0.5000.0, Culture=neutral,  
     PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a"
     validate="false"/>

The version and public key token are the only things that are different from the mapping used in 1.0. Then you just need to have a .vsdisco file in your virtual directory that looks like this:

<dynamicDiscovery
  xmlns="urn:schemas-dynamicdiscovery:disco.2000-03-17" />

When you request the .vsdisco file, the handler will automatically generate a DISCO document describing all the Web services found in the vroot subtree.

entry.title: re: Enabling support for .vsdisco in 1.1
entry.content: Nice information. Could you elaborate on those security concerns?

entry.title: re: Enabling support for .vsdisco in 1.1
entry.content: The way things were configured in 1.0 basically opened the door others to retrieve details about all of the Web services in the directory structure, and most people didn't realize that that was the case.

entry.title: re: Enabling support for .vsdisco in 1.1

entry.title: Trip Report
entry.content:
Last week was awesome. I spent the week in Redmond teaching DevelopMentor's Essential Web Services .NET course to some Microsoft folks. Students can either make or break a class. These students were great - I really enjoyed my time with them.

The timing of the course was great because it was the same week as the Global MVP Summit, which has been discussed quite thoroughly in the blogsphere. So I was finally able to meet some of the other XML/WS MVPs that I used to know only via email or blogging. One of the highlights was the WS-Sushi dinner organized by Kirk.

There were a few other awesome dinners, and catching-up-sessoins, during the week and an amazing boat ride that Don blogged about in more detail (thanks Ford!). I can now say that I've seen BillG's house from the lake. Don invited me to stay at Box Suites (the service is amazing btw) so I had plenty of time to hang out him and Tim, and to get caught up on the fast moving world of Microsoft.

I got home late Friday night, and as I thought about the trip, I realized that it's truly the people that make Microsoft such an amazing place, even if it's just for a week.

entry.title: The XML Files: XML Data Migration Case Study (GEDCOM)
entry.content:
Several years ago I fell in love with the System.Xml APIs because of the wonderful extensibility model. Specifically, the framework for writing custom XmlReader, XmlWriter, and XPathNavigator implementations. While experimenting with the model, I crufted up several XML provider implementations for a variety of interesting data sources like the file system, the registry, .NET assemblies, zip files, and others. Although these were interesting examples, they weren't really more than examples. In other words, they didn't attack a specific problem or provide for any compelling applications.

Lately I've been doing a lot of work with genealogy data forms (GEDCOM 5.0 and GEDCOM 6.0), which are wildly different forms - the former isn't even XML 1.0 compatible. This area of work finally gave me a practical reason to write a custom XmlReader that, when applied to our problem domain, simplified numerous data migration challenges in a very elegant way.

Check out the article for more details and sample code.

entry.title: re: The XML Files: XML Data Migration Case Study (GEDCOM)
entry.content: Great article Aaron. I've built a few of my own XmlReaders before, but I always like seeing articles that make you look at how to solve real-world problems with cool & elegant ideas.

entry.title: re: The XML Files: XML Data Migration Case Study (GEDCOM)
entry.content: Interesting. I did the same thing towards the end of last year. I took it a little further though. I converted from XML 5.5 to GEDCOM 6.0 like you did. I also converted the data to a couple of different html formats as well as RDF.

entry.title: Moving from WS-Routing to WS-Addressing Using WSE 2.0
entry.content:
My latest WSE 2.0 article recently hit the MSDN WSDC. The piece covers the issues surrounding Web services routing and the need for transport-neutral addressing, specifically focusing on the move away from WS-Routing towards the new WS-Addressing specification. Core WS-Addressing concepts and implementing secure routing with Web Service Enhancements 2.0 are shown.

The biggest difference with the WS-Addressing approach is the shift towards next-hop routing. This move addresses the serious security challenges presented by the prior WS-Routing techniques.

entry.title: More Details on TechEd Precon: Essential Web Services
entry.content:
The official abstract for my pre-conference session called Essential Web Services is as follows:

“The Microsoft .NET Framework makes it easy to build powerful Web services based on open industry standards, including XML Schema, SOAP, and WSDL. This workshop helps you quickly ramp up on programming Web services using ASP.NET's WebMethods (.asmx), then shows you how to extend this framework using the new Microsoft Web Services Enhancements (WSE) 2.0. Along the way, we cover several WS-* specifications supported by WSE 2.0 and show you how to take advantage of them in your code with a special focus on security.“

I've had numerous inquiries on the distribution of the focus between ASMX and WSE 2.0. The coverage will be as follows: 50% on architecture (protocol stack) and ASMX, and 50% on WSE2.

The WSE2 hands-on components will show you how to take advantage of basic security and policy concepts. We won't have time for much beyond that. There will be additional hands-on-labs (HOL) available during the week (in a proctored environment) that will walk you through additional WSE2 features in more detail.

I would classify the session as "intermediate". You don't have to know a lot about Web services before attending, but you definitely need to be familiar with .NET, and prepared for a firehose of information

entry.title: WSE 2.0 RTM
entry.content:
The highly anticipated WSE 2.0 officially RTMs today, announced by Ballmer in his TechEd keynote this morning. The WSE team really delivered this time around with major improvements in security, policy, and messaging not to mention the huge leap forward in ease-of-use and productivity.

With WSE 2.0, securing Web services with WS-Security, WS-Trust, and Ws-SecureConversation is finally approachable by the masses. The most common use cases have been fully automated through improved WS-Policy support and various new tools.

Here are 10 new features that you should definitely check out:

  1. WSDL generation from SoapService endpoints (via ?wsdl for HTTP or a special SOAP request for other transports including TCP)
  2. WseWsdl2.exe (for generating SoapClient-derived proxy classes)
  3. Improved WSE Settings Tool 
  4. New Security Settings Tool (wizard faciliates generating security policies quickly)
  5. WseCertificate2.exe (for retrieving cert details and modifying private key properties)
  6. Support for OASIS WS-Security standard
  7. Automatic authentication for UsernameToken when password in plain text, and the ability to encrypt UsernameToken headers with a certificate
  8. Support for Kerberos security tokens (requires OS support)
  9. Automatic Secure Conversation (just check a box in the policy wizard)
  10. Custom policy assertion framework

I wrote two Hands-On-Labs for the WSE team that will be made available with the RTM bits. One is one messaging and the other on security & policy. The HOLs walk you through using all of the new features in a very step-by-step fashion. I hope you find them useful.

BTW, I have a “What's New in WSE 2.0” piece coming in The XML Files very soon.

entry.title: TechEd: Ballmer's Keynote
entry.content:
This year's theme: "Do More with Less"

Spending in the IT industry has stabilized after a long "dry out" period for those who were washed by the bubble.  We're getting back to a situation of strong, solid, steady growth throughout IT, and IT has definitely increased in terms of the global world economy. And the pressure to "do more with less" has never been stronger in order to remain competitive.

Ballmer predication: "The next 10 years will bring more innovation than the previous ten years."

Microsoft is spending a tremendous amount of money in R&D. Only Phizer spends more. Innovation is key, but innovation that simplifies and brings things together, not innovation that creates

thousands of new options and different ways to doing things.

Security is job #1. Huge focus in this area. (Combating spam is also a key focus here)

XML is one of the best things that's happened to our dev platform. XML Web Services provides provides integration for the enterprise, which is VERY important to our future.

Web Services Enhancements (WSE) 2.0 RTM's today! WSE2 (pronounced "wizzy") finally brings security to the Web services developers in a high-productivity way. Rebecca Dias came on stage and demo'ed various new WSE2 features in a solution that leveraged the Office IBF framework.

Customer feedback has indicated that the .NET framework has increased productivity, security, and performance over their Win32 counterparts from the past.

Visual Studio 2005 (Whidbey) and SQL Server 2005 (Yukon) are coming next year. Two of the biggest releases ever that increase the application developer experience. Announced VS.NET 2005 "Team System", which facilitates team collaboration with life-cycle tools including the SOA designer known as Whitehorse.
 
Ballmer concluded with some customer case studies, and emphasized his repeated mantra: “Integrated innovation with greater interoperability”

entry.title: TechEd: The Don &amp; Doug Show
entry.content:
Notes from the general session given by Don Box and Doug Purdy today: 

There is only one program and it is still being written.

Choice is an illusion. It's extremely difficult to change The Program. Redeploying the world is not an option. Change must happen incrementally, if at all. The four tenets of SO:

  1. Boundaries are explicit
  2. Services are autonomous
  3. Share schema & contract, not class
  4. Policy-based compatibility

Objective interpretation is an oxymoron. For any XML instance, there are any number of schemas that can describe it.

Good contracts make good neighbors. Defining explicit boundaries facilitates better interactions.

Innovate locally, interop globally. Innovations make our little neighborhood better, but for innovation, we must introduce as little new techonlogy as possible.

How much DOM does the The Program need? COM is necessary to keep our part of The Program running. Indigo will have first-class access to COM in the future.

How much Remoting does The Program need? Remoting is a CLR feature useful for cross appdomain scenarios. Remoting is great for certain scenarios. It's still evolving, improving.

How much ES does The Program need. ES is the easiest way to take advantage of DCOM for fast cross-machine access thanks to the investment in making DCOM fast and secure.

When in doubt, use ASMX. ASMX will be faster than remoting. We're trying to make ASMX and Remoting just as fast as DCOM.

How any WS-* does The Program need? Less.

How much WSE does The Program need? It gives us SSL's behavior in a transport neutral way via WS-Sec, WS-Trust, and WS-SecCon. If you need those today, WSE provides that part of The Program. Facilitates multi-hop, multi-transport scenarios.

Great presentation guys!

entry.title: TechEd: SO Prescriptive Guidance (Richard Turner)
entry.content:
The following is a summary of a talk given by Richard Turner from the Indigo team that provides guidance on choosing between the various options for building SO applications today including ASMX, WSE2, Remoting, DCOM, ES, MSMQ, and the future path to Indigo.

Why is SO important?

  • Services are meant to last. Microsoft is betting the farm on services being everywhere. Indigo is the is one of the most fundamental rewrites in a long time.
  • A common tongue is needed for services to interact: boundary, schema, contract, and policy.
  • An SO environment extends only as far as we agree on the expression onf the boundary.
  • SO systems that want boroadest possible interop will build on the WS-I protocol family.

Which technology should I use and where?

At the service boundary:

  • Build services using ASMX (default). Use ASMX at boundaries.
    • Components should stay within your service boundaries.
    • Closely aligned to SO tenets.
    • Closest alignment with Indigo.
    • Great interop support.
  • Use WSE for advanced Web services (WS-* protocols)

Inside the service boundary:

  • Consider using ASMX within the service boundary too!
  • Use ES if you need its rich services, want to re-use/extend existing ES/COM+ components, path to "Indigo" from ES.

Asynchronous communications:

  • Use System.Messaging if you need asynchronous messaging, reliable messaging and queing, "first and forget" messaging. MSMQ is not going away. It's going to be the underlying engine in Indigo.
  • The System.Messaging API and namespace does not move forward to Indigo. Indigo navtively supports queing semantics.

Remoting:

  • Use remoting where it's absolutely appropriate. Only use it within the service. Great for getting close to the wire. Inproc cross appdomain communications, handling custom wire protocols.
  • Remoting is not the fastest for cross machine access, DCOM is the absolute fastest.
  • Avoid exposing remoted components at service boundaries.
  • Remoting is an object technology, not aligned with SO principles.
  • Limited interop (e.g., only does SOAP rpc/encoded style).
  • Limited future migration to Indigo.
  • Remoting is not going away. It is moving forward, but there will be better solutions in Indigo.

Caveats:

  • ASMX - avoid using low-level extensibility such as the HTTP context model.
  • ES - avoid passing objrefs inside of ES
  • Native COM+ and MSMQ - use System.EnterpriseServices and
  • System.Messaging, do not use native COM+ and MSMQ APIs
  • Remoting - avoid low-level extensibility such as sinks and channels

Distributed technology performance:

Will ASMX slow my app down? What % of your method calls are work?

  • More work than call - probably minimal impact
  • More call than work - possible impact

Will ES slow down my COM+ components?

  • ES requires more work to create and destroy objects.
  • Use JIT activation and pooling to amortize cost over many calls.
  • Done the right way, ES *can* match COM+ perf.
  • See ES perf whitepapers on MSDN.

Remoting vs. ASMX performance:

  • Remoting tcp/binary wins.
  • Binary remoting hosted in IIS next fastest.
  • ASMX is faster than remoting for SOAP.

Component technologies often obscure service boundaries. Design assumptions don't match deployment realities.

Good practices apply across all distributed technologies.

entry.title: TechEd Trip Report
entry.content:
The place was packed with attendees (over 7500 I think) and the atmosphere was energetic. The "cabana" area was a great place to hook up with the various product teams, chat about technology, whiteboard ideas, and even play XBox on some nice plasmas.

The main focus of the show was: security, Web services (WSE), and Whidbey. I spent most of my time with the Web services folks for obvious reasons. I've already blogged about some of my favorite sessions, but there were others I attended and quite liked.

Benjamin Mitchell's session on Web services security using WSE was excellent. His was the clearest presentation I've seen on general security concepts along with concrete code examples. I followed Benjamin's posts religiously last year when I couldn't make it to TechEd, but this was the first chance I had to meet him in person. Very nice chap.

I attended Mark Fussell's session on System.Xml v2, which was jam-packed...I had to sit on the floor for a while until a chair opened up. Mark showed off the various new System.Xml features that come with Whidbey. My favorites are XmlReader's ReadToDescendant, ReadToNextSibling, and ReadAsObject.

I also had a chance to attend David Chappell's session on Biztalk and how it fits in with SO. Even though I don't have much interest in Biztalk at the moment, I was intrigued to watch Chappell speak about a technology that's so misunderstood and disliked by developers. In his usual fashion, he made me fall in love with Biztalk and convinced me that it will have an important place in SO systems in the forseable future. He's sooooo smooth. If I were only half the speaker he is...

Addison Wesley put on a dinner for authors, where I got to hang with some close friends for dinner including Keith Brown, Fritz Onion, and Don Box. We also chatted it up with Doug Purdy (Indigo) and Paul Vick (VB.NET) at our end of the table. Everyone was raving about Vick's new book during dinner (The VB.NET Programming Language) and trying to convince him to port it to C#. Alex Sussman shared some interesting stories from his Wrox-centric past.

The Indigo team put on a fun coding event one night where they showed us the latest object model and then let us port an old remoting app after dinner. Fun exercise. There were quite a few folks there including: Clemens Vasters, Juval Lowy, Benjamin Mitchell, Ted Neward, Brian Randall, Chris Kinsman, and perhaps others I'm forgetting. The MS crowd included Geary Eppley, Doug Purdy, Richard Turner, Yasser Shohoud, Lance Olson and a few others.

I spent some quality time with Richard Turner discussing Indigo migration and prescriptive guidance, which is my hot topic right now.

Matt Powell and I got to hang out a bit, which is always fun. He's the one guy I like to compare notes with him about home life (e.g., scouts, soccer, little league, and such). Matt runs the MSDN Web Services Developer Center. He has some interesting WSE2 post up on his site.

Another fun rendevous: John Lam. He has nearly convinced me that the Nikon D70 is the way to go. Keith has the Canon Digital Rebel so the debate was quite interesting. I'm definitely going to get one of the two. John and I used to teach DevelopMentor's first Web class together way back when. It was fun to hear about his new baby and the new venture at ObjectSharp.

John Bristowe was refreshing to talk to. He's so energetic and excited about implementing anything WS-*. He's all over policy right now with some interesting ideas. He drug me to a whiteboard at one point as he was brainstorming with Don Smith.

The rest of my week was completely focused on getting Pluralsight off the ground. I came home tired, but it sure was fun.

entry.title: WSE2 and WSDL
entry.content:
Ever since my entry about my favorite new WSE2 features, I've had several readers inquire about the new WSDL support. So here are a few more details...

WSE2 can both generate and consume WSDL definitions. It automatically generates WSDL for SoapService derived classes. And it can produce SoapClient derived proxy classes when you feed it WSDL through WseWsdl2.exe.-

How does it generate WSDL?

If the SoapService endpoint is bound to HTTP, simply tack "?wsdl" to the URL and type it into your browser (same as ASMX today).

If the SoapService endpoint is bound to another protocol, say TCP, this approach doesn't work (nor does it make sense). Hence, WSE 2.0 provides a generic approach for requesting WSDL over any transport (similar to what's outlined in WS-MetadataExchange). You can do this by sending a SOAP message with an action of http://schemas.microsoft.com/wse/2003/06/RequestDescription and an empty body as illustrated here:

<soap:Envelope ... xmlns:soap="..." xmlns:wsa="...">
   <soap:Header>
      <wsa:Action>
      http://schemas.microsoft.com/wse/2003/06/RequestDescription
      </wsa:Action>
      ...
   </soap:Header>
   <soap:Body>
      ...
   </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>

Upon receiving this, the WSE 2.0 endpoint will return the WSDL in the response SOAP message. This is what WseWsdl2.exe does behind the scenes when you give it a TCP address. You can try running it while tracing the messages to see it in action.

Yves has more information on what's going on “in the trenches“ of WseWsdl2.exe and how to get WSDL generation going for SoapReceiver-derived classes. He discusses a problem he has generating proxies in this area, which btw I haven't seen while working with SoapService-derived classes.

entry.title: re: WSE2 and WSDL
entry.content: I was referring to the "?wsdl" approach not making sense for TCP-based services. You can use wsewsdl2.exe to automatically retrieve WSDL from TCP-based services without writing any code.

3. From the VS IDE 'Add Web Reference'

Each proxy ends up inheriting from a different base class.
1.Public Class someProxy
Inherits System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapHttpClientProtocol
2.Public Class someProxy

entry.title: Systems that Last
entry.content:
Something that's hit me recently: the main motivation for moving towards service orientation (SO) is that it facilitates building systems that last. This observation resonates with me as the primary factor for adopting the SO paradigm. It seems that enterprises are more concerned now than every about being able to build systems that can truly pass the test of time and freely adapt to the ever-changing technology landscape. The principles of SO make this possible.

SO's adaptability stems from designing around explicit boundaries and minimal assumptions. Reducing the surface area of contracts (both structurally and semantically) buys freedom when it comes to implementation, deployment, versioning, and management. Building a distributed system with traditional OO technologies committed the enterprise to particular platforms and technologies, which made it difficult to adjust down the road.

Building a distributed system based on SO buys freedom when it comes to implementation choices, deployment, versioning, and management. As enterprises move towards SO, they'll also be moving away from the days of redesigning the entire system each time a new technology appears.

entry.title: re: Systems that Last
entry.content:
"...Building a distributed system with traditional OO technologies committed the enterprise to particular platforms and technologies..."

Aaron, I think this statement could be a little misleading to some people. I don't think you want to run the risk of people interpreting it as "Uh oh, I guess I should abandon all my OO knowledge from the past few years."

After all, services have to actually be built somehow and have their internals written, and we're all still going to do that with "traditional OO technologies". As you said, the design of the boundaries is the key, and those boundaries now become a major focus during the design phase of an application (and probably one of the first things tackled, or at least should be).

The loosey-coupled nature of service orientation will allow for longer-lasting systems because the endpoints of a service could care less about what platform/technology it was written in and what platform/technology they are being consumed by.

entry.title: re: Systems that Last
entry.content:
I'm also interested to see what the negative impacts of this will be. Surely most of us have been in an organization with one or two old, creaky systems built with the flavor of the day...from 1983. Given that the churn in technology inside service boundaries is unlikely to stop in the next ten years (think Longhorn), will we find ourselves maintaining heterogeneous systems forever, as systems last longer and longer?

But maybe it's a good thing: presumably COBOL programmers can charge high rates these days. :)

entry.title: Geek Notes 2004-07-04
Microsoft Culture
Microsoft Culture
WSE 2.0 UsernameToken Authentication Tidbits
entry.content:
WSE 2.0 provides two main authentication models: 

  • Windows authentication. WSE 2.0 automatically authenticates incoming UsernameTokens (via LogonUser) when the password is supplied in plain text (PasswordOptions.SendPlainText). You should only use this option if:
  • You encrypt the UsernameToken element
  • You're using a secure channel (e.g. SSL)
  • Custom authentication. WSE 2.0 makes it possible to implement a custom authentication scheme through a UsernameTokenManager-derived class (UTM). This allows you to store credentials in SQL Server, for example. It also has the following benefits:
  • You can send a hashed password (PasswordOptions.SendHashed). WSE will regenerate the hash from the password it gets from your UTM as proof-of-possession.
  • You can sign the message with a UsernameToken and avoid sending the password altogether (PasswordOptions.SendNone). WSE will verify the signature using the password it gets from your UTM as proof-of-possession.

You should always sign your SOAP messages when security is an issue. Hence, the last option (UTM + signature + SendNone) is probably the best fit. Unless you need to use Windows authentication for some reason, then you should use one of the first options (SendPlainText + encryption).

entry.title: WSE 2.0 Authentication and Managing Passwords
entry.content:
John brings up an great question related to my last post on UsernameToken (UT) authentication with WSE 2.0 (see comments). When you take the custom authentication route and write a UsernameTokenManager (UTM), your implementation of AuthenticateToken must return the same secret (e.g., password) used on the client side to generate the hash/signature, depending on which option you use. This is necessary because WSE needs to recalculate the hash/signature and verify that it's the same. So when the client-side uses passwords, your UTM must have access to the plain text passwords of all the users.

This approach makes security experts, like Keith Brown, cringe because if the machine is ever compromised, so are all of the passwords. And since most users typically use the same password everywhere, compromising it can have a far-reaching effect. The only way around this is to have the sender and receiver agree on an algorithm for generating a secret from the original password and use it instead of the original. Hence, the client would supply the generated secret when instantiating the UT, and the machine would store the generated password somewhere on the machine. The rest of the process would work the same. This approach doesn't protect the server if it's compromised, but the real passwords are safe.

This happens to be Keith's biggest complaint about WSE 2.0 but he has some great ideas on how to make it better. I'll let him explain rather than steal his thunder.

entry.title: re: WSE 2.0 Authentication and Managing Passwords

entry.title: WSE 2.0 Authentication: How To Avoid ClearText Passwords With UsernameToken
WSE 2.0 Authentication: How To Avoid ClearText Passwords With UsernameToken
Interesting WSE2 UsernameToken Authentication Discussion
Avoiding Cleartext Passwords
entry.content:
Keith's suggestion for avoiding cleartext passwords seems totally feasible to me. The question is what to use for scopeURI. One approach is to use the endpoint address, scoping the validator to all operations available at the endpoint. Another approach is to use the action, scoping the validator to the specific operation. Either seems reasonable but using action seems more appropriate to me for some reason.

When Keith says that WSE2 literally uses cleartext passwords, I think he means that the automated support for hashing/signatures relies on the cleartext password provided when instantiating a UsernameToken. However, it seems possible to implement Keith's technique using WSE2 today by supplying his notion of validator (for the password) when instantiating theUsernameToken on the client, and generating and returning the same validator from your UTM on the server. Then WSE2 will use the validator for hashing/signing instead of the cleartext password. I'm itch'in to try this now.

entry.title: re: Avoiding Cleartext Passwords
entry.content: That's what I meant, yes. You can absolutely implement my scheme on top of WSE. I just wish that the original spec had considered this so that the WSE guys would have felt comfortable building in support for something like this from the get go.

entry.title: re: Avoiding Cleartext Passwords
entry.content:
[quote]
Either seems reasonable but using action seems more appropriate to me for some reason.
[/quote]

I would take the 'action' option since it would more explicitly scope it to the action being performed. (one endpoint, many services, different security schemes possible?)

Looking at current implementations, the 'action' level security granularity is preferred by most.

my 2ct worth

entry.title: Interesting WSE2 UsernameToken Authentication Discussion
Installing the WSE 2.0 Sample Certificates
entry.content:
I've received several queries about how to properly install the sample certificates that ship with the WSE 2.0 samples. It's easy to get things mixed up when installing them.

These certs are used by the X.509 samples. and if they're not installed properly, the samples will simply not work properly. The sample certificates were generated by the makecert tool provided in the Microsoft Platform Software Development Kit. You can use these sample certs to test X.509 functionality in your own applications, but you should not use them in a production environment. Instead, you should contact a certificate authority and request your own certificate.

The following instructions (which I originally wrote for the WSE 2.0 Hands-On-Labs) describe how to install the WSE 2.0 sample certificates:

  • Open an MMC console by pressing Start, press Run, type mmc, and then click OK.
  • On the File menu, click Add/Remove Snap-in
  • Click Add, under Snap-in, double-click Certificates. 
  • Click My user account to add the certificates for the current user. Click Finish.
  • Click Add, under Snap-in, double-click Certificates. 
  • Click Computer account for the local machines certificates. Click Finish.
  • Close the dialog boxes.
  • In the console tree, under Certificates - Current User\Personal, click Certificates. 
  • Open the Certificate Import wizard by selecting Action | All Tasks and choose Import. 
  • Follow the wizard. When asked for the file to import, specify: C:\Program Files\Microsoft WSE\v2.0\Samples\Sample Test Certificates\Client Private.pfx.
  • When asked for the private key password, specify: wse2qs.
  • Finish the wizard.

Note: this certificate will be used by our client application to sign messages sent to the service. It could also be used to identify the client for authentication purposes.

  • In the console tree, under Certificates (Local Computer)\Personal, click Certificates. 
  • Open the Certificate Import wizard by selecting Action | All Tasks and choose Import. 
  • Follow the wizard. When asked for the file to import, specify: C:\Program Files\Microsoft WSE\v2.0\Samples\Sample Test Certificates\Server Private.pfx.
  • When asked for the private key password, specify: wse2qs.
  • Finish the wizard.

Note: this certificate will be used to encrypt messages between the applications. The client application will use the public key to encrypt the message and the service will use the private key to decrypt the message. The client needs to have the public portion of the certificate available in the Current User store.

  • In the console tree, under Certificates - Current User\Other People, click Certificates.

Note: if you don't have an Other People store under Current User, open Internet Explorer, select Tools, Internet Options, Content, and press the Certificates button. You should see an Other People tab in the certificates dialog. You can import the certificate here through this interface or you can return to mmc and refresh the Current User tree and Other People should now show up.

  • Open the Certificate Import wizard by selecting Action | All Tasks and choose Import. 
  • Follow the wizard. When asked for the file to import, specify: C:\Program Files\Microsoft WSE\v2.0\Samples\Sample Test Certificates\Server Public.cer.
  • Finish the wizard.

Note: this certificate only contains the public portion of Server Private.pfx. The client will use this to encrypt messages and the server will use the private key installed in the Local Machine store to decrypt the messages.

You should now be set to begin using the WSE 2.0 sample certificates!

I've been using it a lot lately on various family and church outings and I've been able to capture shots that were impossible with other cameras I've owned.

I'm really happy with this camera. My satisfaction level seems to go up with each use. If you're in the market for a digital SLR, I definitely recommend it.

entry.title: What's New in WSE 2.0
entry.content:
My What's New in WSE 2.0 piece is now online on the MSDN Magazine site. The outline of the article is basically as follows:

  • Compatibility
  • Side-by-side execution
  • Installation
  • Project configuration
  • Messaging API enhancements
  • WSDL support
  • Security/policy enhancements
  • WSE Security Settings tool
  • Automatic secure conversation
  • Next-hop routing

Because of the breadth, it doesn't get too deep in any of these areas but it should give you a feel for all the new features in this release.

entry.title: Indigo SDR
entry.content:
I had the privelege of spending the last two days in Redmond at another Indigo SDR, where the team showed us the latest version of the architecture/object model and let us play with some bits in exchange for feedback. My NDAs prevent me from going into detail, but I can say that it was great to see how much progress they've made and how clean everything is starting to look.

The team really seems to be intensely focused on the user experience. During Don & Steve's talk they said:

“Our goal: if you're a fan of any of these technologies (COM, COM+, MSMQ, .NET Remoting, ASMX, WSE2), you're going to like the Indigo experience better.”

At times it seems like the Indigo team may be biting off more than they can chew, with all of the issues around trying to bring all of these technologies under a single umbrella, but it's going to be a wonderful world if they can pull it off and make everyone happy.

I can't wait until Beta 1.

entry.title: Indigo SDR
Indigo SDR
When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
I'm just curious. It's time for a little survey on Indigo expectations:

  1. What's more important to you: a) getting Indigo sooner, but perhaps with less features and tool support (update) for now, b) waiting longer in order to get a more complete package and better migration, etc.?
  2. What are your expectations on Indigo performance relative to existing technologies: a) it must be faster, b) it must be close to the same, c) it must be within an order of magnitude, d) it doesn't matter.

Post your comments. Let me know what you think.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
1. a) Sooner, if the programming model is complete and sound. Features can always be added, but architecture is hard to change.
b) I think they're putting way too much emphasis on migration. I would rather have a cleaner programming model for Indigo. Specifically, trying to enable mechanical migration from distributed object technology to a message-based technology is a fool's errand.

2. I'm pretty sure if they make the feature set properly composable, we'll be able to achieve performance for our apps that's better than what we can get with existing technologies.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
Easy ...
1) Later, I want it complete, my customers want it 'complete' ... no SPs or updates, just out of the box.
2) Must be faster.

Christian

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
1) I vote for later, as long as the use cases, extensibility, and design is correct. I don't want to have to deal with breaking changes. That doesn't mean that I don't want it now, but I don't want to pay the price for getting it rushed out the door.

2) As far as performance is concerned, my expectations depend on the context. For calls that are migrated from ES (on a LAN, no firewall, etc, etc), I expect the same performance. Don Box said that when WS-Policy calls indicate that you are talking Indigo to Indigo, there will be some pretty crazy optimizations. When doing distributed transactions over the web, however, I can't say my expectation is too high in terms of performance. I'll accept some slowdown (and I know it is coming, as the parsing of XML is always going to give you a hit), but I don't know that I will accept an order of magnitude.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
1. b - complete. I don't want to have to migrate twice or hold off using it because Indigo is not quite "fully baked" yet.

2. a-b - basically like Nicholas said, it depends. But I would not expect a slowdown, especially considering my answer to question 1.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
I'd like to make a distinction between shipping Indigo and releasing a beta.

I want it to ship when it's done. That said, I want to get my hands dirty with some early bits now.

entry.title: Indigo ship? Never
entry.content:
Let's see - we had 4 good years or so of using and getting proficient with Visual Sudio 6.0. To the point of mastering the technology; being completely comfortable using it.

So now between 2002, original release of VS.NET, oh, sorry 2003 for VS2003, oh, sorry 2005 for VS2005, whoops 2006 VSLongHorn, we have 4 products in 4 years. How can MS expect any developer to get acclimated and productive using a product if they change it every year?

So don't ship Indigo - EVER. Or at least until we get VS200X under our belts.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
1) Definitely later. Everything we've read says that it's a fairly major shift over the current stuff. Let it simmer and get it right out of the gate... though I do agree with Christian that an early-ish beta would help with the learning curve for that shift.

2) At least as fast as the existing technology.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content: I probably should have rephrased the first question to focus more on the importance of wiz-bang tools that make Indigo easier to use. I assumed that no one would want it to ship with anything less than a solid architecture and OM. How important are productivity tools when it comes to scheduling the release? Should the lack of tools hold it up?

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
Productivity tools are important. While XML is important, and Indigo relies heavly upon it, as Juval Lowy would say "the developer should never see XML".

Fortunately, from what I have seen of the Indigo programming model (and what Doug Purdy says in an interview with Don Box), you don't see any of that. If you don't want to get that low level, and don't care (even though you should to some degree), you don't have to.

I mean, in the Indigo model, how many tools can you provide really? You already have a class designer, which will allow you to define the implementation of your business functionality. You can then use the refactoring features in VS.NET 2005 to extract the interface which eventually gets attributed for Indigo. All you have to do is wire up the attributes and fire up the service environment. I think that all the core pieces that you need for a development environment for Indigo is there already, you just need to place some glue there.

I mean, it would be great if I had a template for a service host to start up the service environment, but I can use notepad for that. =)

The only big piece missing would be to maybe have a nice user interface where I can check off options for a service environment, and it would produce the code to set it up, or the XML configuration file which could be loaded to provide the same options.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content: 1) sooner 2) similar

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content: We don't need no stinkin' tool support. ;) I assume by tools you mean like the WSE config tool that integrates into VS. I think this is important for a production release, but definitely not a big issue for people who want to play with beta bits.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
1) If it's "tool support", then sooner. Otherwise, wait to ship it until it's done. However, give us betas early so when it ships we've already prepared for it and know somewhat how to use it.

2) Faster. On almost all other things (like .net 2.0), I'd say "similar". For WSE2.0, I would have said "order of magnitude". But if this is be an interface to or one-stop replacement for DCOM, COM+, WS-I, remoting, etc, then it must be faster. Similar will almost cut the mustard, but please say "we waited to ship six extra months, but it's now 12% faster" instead.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
I think that the criteria for shipping are:

- The "Four Tenets of Service-Orientation" are well-supported in the tools. Service descriptions obviously can't be just centered around CLR types expressed as XSD. Support for canonical schemas (WXS for now, others later) with transforms to define message parts would really complete the service-orientation picture.

- Performance of a no-op Indigo operation for a given protocol and security mechanism should somewhat match a similar WSE 2.0 no-op (+/- 20%). I guess the only relevant comparison is WSE/ASMX and an Indigo endpoint hosted in IE. Does anyone think it's useful to compare Indigo and WSE 2.0 SP1 sans IIS?

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
I use BizTalk 2004 a lot and I don't want Indigo attached to BTS2K4 until it is well supported by the BTS development environment, very well documented and very well integrated. The amount of grief I get delivering projects under pressure because the tool purports to supporting something but clearly does it poorly is driving me insane. This is amplified in BTS because you are often so far from the code face that working around an inadequacy in the tool that abstracts X is so painful.

For example, if the MIME encoder or MSMQC adapter does not quite do what you expect then you are in a world of pain. If the Indigo adapter is not superb I dread to think...

Performance? We can't go backwards at least as this will discourage quite a few from moving to it as matter of course. Scaleability. Yes please please.

entry.title: re: When should Indigo ship?
entry.content:
We are interested in seeing a complete implementation of Indigo without the need to constantly rework our strategies and approaches. I am not so concerned with migration as I would like to think that so many improvements will come from Indigo that we would want to revisit, or at least reconfirm our architecture.

Must be faster. With the advent of improved binary formats to move XML infosets on the wire etc., and an ability for the messaging infrastructure to decide on the optimum transport for the particular situation, how can it be any worse???

Nevertheless, I don't want to have to wait for a long time either as I'd hate to think that we're working on a system with a chance of having to rebuild again, and again, and again...
